It is of great economic value and environmental significance to extend the service life of commercial SCR catalysts. Water and acid wash as well as thermal regeneration were often used to remove toxic substances (such as dust, metal sulfates and metal chlorides) residual on catalyst surface so as to reduce the replacement frequency of catalyst, but easily lead to the loss of active components. In this paper, impregnation method was used to supplement the lost active components of the spent honeycombed V2O5-WO3/TiO2 (labeled as VW/Ti) catalyst, and the effects of drying duration and impregnation solution concentration on NH3-SCR performance of catalyst were studied. The results showed that the catalyst dried for 6 h at 110 °C exhibited the best deNO x activity and sulfur/water resistance. Further prolonging or shortening drying duration reduced the catalytic activity instead. It can be attributed that proper drying duration constructs abundant pore channels inside catalyst, optimizes active components dispersion, reduces diffusion resistance of reactants into the inner surface and provides more effective active sites on catalyst surface for adsorption and oxidation of reactants. With rise of V content in impregnation solution from 1.06 wt.% to 3.61 wt.%, deNO x activity as well as SO2/H2O resistance of catalyst improves at 150–300 °C. Besides, key influence factors are also discussed based on reaction kinetics analysis. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Catalyst regeneration Spent catalyst Drying process deNO x SO2/H2O resistance Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Nitrogen oxide (NO x ) is one of the representative air pollutants from fossil fuel combustion. It causes acid rain, photochemical smog and ozone layer destruction, and is quite harmful to ecological environment and biological health [1]. In addition, NO x is also a typical greenhouse gas, whose global warming potential (GWP) is about 300 times higher than that of CO2 [2]. Therefore, denitration is of great significance to control environmental pollution and achieve "double carbon" goal proposed by Chinese government. Stringent emission standard (100 mg/Nm3) has been promulgated in China (GB13223–2011), which is further tightened to 30–50 mg/Nm3 in Beijing (DB11-139-015), Shanghai (DB31387-2017) and Hangzhou (DB201). Selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 (NH3-SCR) has been widely applied as post-combustion deNO x technology due to its low cost and high efficiency [3]. Vanadium tungsten titanium (V2O5-WO3/TiO2) catalyst is the most commonly used SCR catalyst with high efficiency and strong SO2 resistance [4,5]. However, fly ash particles, acid gasses, alkali/alkaline earth metals and heavy metals in flue gas gradually deactivate SCR catalysts [6–8], making their service life be usually 2–3 years [9]. The spent V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst containing vanadium [10,11] and various heavy metals [12,13] has been classified as hazardous waste and cannot be discarded without proper disposal. Furthermore, the annual production of spent SCR catalysts in China was estimated to be 2.5 × 105∼3.0 × 105 m³ after 2020 [9]. An approach either extracts the metal elements (such as V, Ti, and etc.) from waste SCR catalyst or makes the deactivated catalyst regenerated is significantly demanded [14,15]. Catalyst regeneration methods including washing with water or acid and thermal regeneration are frequently used to prolong the service life and reduce the replacement of catalysts. Washing with water or acid [16] refers to rinsing catalysts with high-pressure deionized water or sulfuric acid/ nitric acid [14,17] to remove ash, ammonium sulfate and alkali/alkaline earth metals attached on catalyst surface. Thermal regeneration is a method that treats deactivated catalysts at high temperature (300–800 °C) under air [18], water vapor [19], acid [20], reducing [21] or inert [22] atmospheres to decompose and/or expel poisons on catalyst. However, all the above regeneration methods cause the loss of active components [15], resulting in incomplete recovery of catalytic activity. Therefore, an economical and efficient method to replenish active component onto catalyst is particularly significant for catalyst regeneration. Impregnation is an economical method with high application potential for adding active components to waste catalyst [14,15], which mainly includes impregnation, drying and calcination processes. In impregnation process, catalyst carrier is immersed into solution with active component precursors, and the solution with active component precursors not only adheres to the carrier surface, but also enters the pores of carrier due to capillary action. Gallastegi et al. [23] found that V content in impregnating solution increasing from 3 wt.% to 8 wt.% improves the SCR activity of catalyst at 100–300 °C, for higher V content in impregnating solution constructs highly polymerized V species with more redox sites. However, Zhao et al. [24] found increasing V content from 9 wt.% to 13 wt.% decreases the deNO x activity at 150–400 °C. Drying process removes the external and internal moisture at 105–120 °C with air. During this process, the active component precursors are redistributed and the pores are reconstructed on catalyst [25]. Abdouss et al. [25] found the catalyst dried for 16 h possesses a large specific surface area, which achieves the high dispersion of spherical active particles and has excellent redox performance at low temperature. However, insufficient or excessive drying deteriorates the distribution of catalyst active components. Therefore, appropriate impregnating solution concentration and dry duration should be determined so as to replenish the active component of waste SCR catalyst economically and efficiently. In this paper, impregnation method was used to supplement active components of spent SCR catalyst. The effects of impregnating solution concentration and drying duration on the regenerated SCR activity and sulfur/water resistance of the honeycomb monolith SCR catalyst were studied based on NH3-SCR experiments and catalytic characterizations. It provides experimental foundation for building an economical and feasible regeneration process suitable for spent SCR catalyst. Experimental Catalyst preparation and characterization The honeycomb monolith V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst with 0.34, 1.60 and 44.36 wt.% of V, W and Ti represents the used SCR catalyst (labeled as VW/Ti-W). Its active component was supplemented using ultrasonic assisted impregnation method [26]. Firstly, 0.552 or 1.982 g ammonium metavanadate (Adamas, RG), 0.519 or 1.983 g ammonium metatungstate (Leyan, purity of 99.5%) and oxalic acid (Adamas, RG) were mixed in 50 or 48 mL deionized water respectively with stirring for 1 h, and then ultrasonically treated for 2 h to obtain low (V con. = 1.06 wt.% and W con. = 1.00 wt.%) and high (V con. = 3.61 wt.% and W con. = 3.61 wt.%) concentration impregnating solutions. Subsequently, catalyst unit with long × wide × high = 15 mm × 15 mm × 40 mm (shown in Fig. S1) was impregnated in the above prepared impregnating solutions for 4 h. Afterwards, the impregnated catalyst unit was dried by hot air (110 °C) for 1, 6 or 12 h after drain off and then calcinated at 350 °C in air for 3 h. The above prepared catalyst is denoted as VL/HW/Ti-y, where subscript L or H represents the catalyst impregnated using low concentration or high concentration solution, respectively and y refers to drying duration. The actual V and W loadings of VLW/Ti-y are 0.60 and 2.40 wt.% and those of VHW/Ti-y are 1.30 and 2.91 wt.% (determined by EDS). The prepared fresh VL/HW/Ti-y catalysts as well as the VW/Ti-W catalyst were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption/desorption, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), H2- temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and NH3- temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD). The detailed equipment models and operating conditions are listed in supplementary material. Catalytic activity and stability test NH3-SCR activity and SO2/H2O resistance of the honeycomb catalyst were carried out in a quartz tube fixed-bed reactor (inner diameter × length = 23 mm × 500 mm). The reactor with honeycomb VW/Ti catalyst (about 9 cm3) was installed inside an electric furnace and its temperature was controlled at 150–450 °C. The simulated flue gas consisted of NO (500 ppm), NH3 (500 ppm), O2 (5 vol.%), SO2 (50–500 ppm, when added), H2O (5–20 vol.%, when added) and N2(as balance). H2O was injected by a micro-injection pump [27]. The total gas flow was controlled at 900 mL/min by mass flow controllers (CS200, Beijing sevenstar flow Co., Ltd.) corresponding to a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 6000 h−1. NO x inlet and outlet concentrations (denoted as C inlet and C outlet respectively) were monitored by flue gas analyzer (Delta 2000CD-IV, MRU), and NO x conversion (%) was calculated according to Eq. (1). Each test was repeated at least twice to ensure the data accuracy. (1) NO x conversion ( % ) = C i n l e t − C o u t l e t C i n l e t × 100 % Results and discussion NH3-SCR activity evaluation The NH3-SCR activities of four VW/Ti catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . In comparison with VLW/Ti-1 and VLW/Ti-12, VLW/Ti-6 exhibits the highest SCR activity in the range of 150–350 °C, and its NO x conversion reaches 94.8 % at the temperature as low as 250 °C. The better SCR activity of VLW/Ti-6 at relatively low temperature due to its proper drying duration. It results in better active component distribution and more abundant pore structure on catalyst surface. At the beginning of drying process, temperature gradient exists between the preferentially heated outer surface of catalyst and its bulk phase. The evaporation rate of external moisture is faster than that inside. It leads to the formation of water concentration gradient in catalyst, providing a continuous driving force for water diffusion outwards as well as its evaporation. At the same time, preferential evaporation of external water also leads to a higher concentration of active components on external surface of catalyst than that inside the catalyst. The formed concentration gradient of active components drives the active components distribution inwards the inner channels of carrier. Proper drying duration (6 h) allows the adequate out-penetration of internal moisture on catalyst, which constructs abundant pore structure on internal and external surfaces of catalyst. It reduces the diffusion resistance of reactants and achieves the high distribution of active components on catalyst surface. As drying duration is shortened to 1 h, the out-penetration and evaporation of moisture are insufficient. Partial moisture may still residual on the pore channels of catalyst, which hinders the high dispersion of active components as well as the internal diffusion of reactants. It properly explains the lower SCR activity of VLW/Ti-1. Further prolonging the drying duration barely contributes to the reconstruction of new pore channels or to the redistribution of active components. On the contrary, it causes the collapse or shrinkage of the formed pores, so that reduces the catalyst specific surface area and active components dispersion. As for VHW/Ti-6, its NO x conversion increases obviously at 150–350 °C but decreases more dramatically above 350 °C than that of VLW/Ti-6. This phenomenon can be explained that increasing V and W contents improves the redox capacity of catalyst, but aggravated excessive oxidation of NH3 [28,29]. SO2/H2O tolerance evaluation SO2 and H2O in actual flue gas always lead to catalyst deactivation. The resistance of VLW/Ti-6 and VHW/Ti-6 catalysts to SO2/H2O at 200 and 300 °C are shown in Fig. 2 (a)(b). The result indicates that VLW/Ti-6 and VHW/Ti-6 catalysts have excellent SO2/H2O tolerance. The SCR activity of VLW/Ti-6 catalyst decreases slightly at 200 °C as SO2 increasing from 50 ppm to 400 ppm, while that increases to 85 % with 500 ppm SO2. After turning off SO2, the SCR activity of VLW/Ti-6 catalyst still maintains at original level (Fig. 2(a)). The excellent SO2 tolerance of VLW/Ti-6 catalyst can be owed to the following reasons: firstly, the presence of WO3 facilitates the decomposition of the formed NH4HSO4 or (NH4)2SO4 to SO2, for W atom increases the electron cloud density of S6+ in SO4 2− or HSO4 − [30]; secondly, the introduction of SO2 forming sulfate species on catalyst surface can provide extra acid sites for NH3 adsorption and improve NH3-SCR reaction instead [31]; thirdly, Ti atoms are more easily combined with SO4 2− to form TiSO4 than V atoms, so that protects V atoms from sulfuration [32,33]; furthermore, proper drying time optimizes the pore structure and active component distribution of catalyst, which also enhances the SO2 resistance of catalyst. Increasing temperature to 300 °C, the NO x conversion of VLW/Ti-6 catalyst is independent of SO2 concentration within 50–500 ppm and maintains at 99% for 3.5 h. It properly because higher reaction temperature accelerates the redox cycle of VW/Ti catalyst and promotes the decomposition of the deposited sulfate species. According to previous studies, higher V loading can improve the redox ability of VW/Ti catalyst, but also promotes the oxidation of SO2 to SO3 and aggravates sulfur poisoning [34]. However, VHW/Ti-6 catalyst in this study achieves higher and more stable NO x conversion than VLW/Ti-6 catalyst at 200 °C. That's because the VO x surface density of VHW/Ti-6 (3.18 VO x /nm2, the calculation details and results shown in supplementary material and Table 1 , respectively) is higher than that of VLW/Ti-6 (1.43 VO x /nm2), even so is still lower than 7.9 VO x /nm2. It manifests that V atoms of VHW/Ti-6 distribute as sub-monolayer and partial Ti atoms can still be exposed to react preferentially with SO2 [32,33], protecting the surface V atoms. The influence of H2O on SCR activity and its stability of VW/Ti catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 (b). After adding 20 vol.% H2O at 200 °C, the NO x conversion of VLW/Ti-6 decreases from 81 % to 75 % within 10 min and then remains stable for 180 min. It indicates H2O has negative effect on NH3-SCR reaction, possibly because: (a) H2O shows competitive adsorption with reactants [19,35]; (b) the dissociated adsorption of H2O converts Lewis acid (denoted as L acid) to Brønsted acid (denoted as B acid) through V=O + H2O = V-OH + -OH, reducing the formation of active intermediate NH2 [36]. Rising temperature to 300 °C, H2O addition barely influences the SCR activity of VLW/Ti-6 catalyst. It mainly because higher temperature increases the saturated vapor pressure of H2O and reduces the adsorption of H2O on catalyst surface, so that alleviates the competitive adsorption between H2O and reactants. Interesting phenomenon was observed on VHW/Ti-6 catalyst that its NO x conversion at 200 °C increases from 94% to 98% after adding 20 vol.% H2O. It indicates VHW/Ti-6 catalyst with higher V and W contents enhances the redox ability of catalyst and facilitates the dissociation of the adsorbed H2O to produce OH group, which provides more active sites for NH3 adsorption [35]. Villamaina et al. [37] observed similar results that H2O showed a positive effect on NH3-SCR reaction, for H2O accelerated the formation of intermediates such as NO3 − and NH4 + [38]. The positive effect of H2O can be further confirmed that the NO x conversions of VLW/Ti-6 and VHW/Ti-6 catalysts drop after stopping H2O. As SO2 (100 ppm) and H2O (5–20 vol.%) coexists, the NO x conversion of VLW/Ti-6 catalyst can still reach 99% and maintains for about 3 h at 300 °C (Fig. S2). It further verifies the regenerated VW/Ti catalysts whose active components supplemented by impregnation method can not only restore the SCR activity but also obtain excellent resistance to SO2 and H2O. Characterization results Morphology, crystal phase and pore size distribution Catalyst characterizations were conducted to investigate the microstructures as well as the physicochemical properties of the VW/Ti catalysts. The morphologies of VW/Ti-W, VLW/Ti-1, VLW/Ti-6, VLW/Ti-12 and VHW/Ti-6 catalysts were explored by SEM and TEM and displayed in Fig. 3 . As observed in the SEM images, particles with relatively large sizes (20–32 nm) and more surface mesoporous structures are formed in VLW/Ti-1 and VLW/Ti-6, especially for the latter one. However, the arrangement of the surface particles seems more compact and agglomerated in VLW/Ti-12, which causes the disappearance of partial surface pore structures. It supports the above conjecture that proper drying duration can construct abundant pore structure on catalyst surface, while over drying results in the deterioration of catalyst morphology. VHW/Ti-6 possesses larger particle size and less pore structure, due to the assembled active components on catalyst surface. From all the TEM images, overlapping of V2O5 (200) lattice plane (interplanar crystal spacing = 0.58 nm), WO3 (202) lattice plane (interplanar crystal spacing = 0.26 nm) and TiO2 (101) lattice plane (interplanar crystal spacing = 0.35 nm) are found, reflecting the dispersion of active components onto catalyst support [39–41]. According to the XRD pattern of all catalysts (Fig. 4 ), merely the diffraction peaks belonging to anatase TiO2 (JCPDS NO.21–1276) are raised [42], indicating that VO x and WO x species in all catalysts exist either in amorphous or microcrystal form, which is difficult to be detected [14]. Compared with VLW/Ti-1, the TiO2 diffraction peaks in VLW/Ti-6 significantly are weakened. It is reasonable to believe appropriate drying duration enhances the interaction of VO x and WO x with TiO2, which makes TiO2 lattice structure distorted [43]. However, those diffraction peaks in VLW/Ti-12 become enhanced. It can be attributed to the excessive desiccation that leads to the agglomeration of VO x and WO x species and exposes more TiO2 crystals to be detected. The diffraction peaks in VHW/Ti-6 are stronger than those of VLW/Ti-6. This result implies that the polymeric VO x and WO x species may be formed due to their higher contents, which avoids the distortion of TiO2 crystal structure by the inner migrated V and W atoms [44]. The above conclusion can be further verified by the SBET, Vtot, Dave and VO x surface density values of the regenerated catalysts which are listed in Table 1. It can be seen that VLW/Ti-6 possesses the largest S BET (54.61 m2/g) and V tot (0.22 cm3/g), those of VLW/Ti-1 and VLW/Ti-12 catalysts reduce, especially for VLW/Ti-12 catalyst. Moreover, the VO x surface densities of VW/Ti catalysts are calculated as follows: VLW/Ti-6 (1.43 VO x /nm2) < VLW/Ti-1 (1.57 VO x /nm2) < VLW/Ti-12 (2.37 VO x /nm2) < VHW/Ti-6 (3.18 VO x /nm2). The lowest VO x surface densities of VLW/Ti-6 confirms the proper desiccation duration can construct abundant pore structures in catalyst and achieve the high distribution of active components on both inner and outer surfaces of catalyst. However, inadequate or excessive desiccation results in the residual of water molecules on inner pore of catalyst or collapse and shrinkage of the pores, respectively. Both of them make the inner distribution of active components difficult. VHW/Ti-6 owns the highest VO x surface density due to its highest V loading, but that is still lower than 7.8 VO x /nm2. It indicates a sub-monolayer structure of VO x on VHW/Ti-6 catalyst. However, the S BET (48.73 m2/g) and V tot (0.20 cm3/g) values of VHW/Ti-6 catalyst decreases obviously comparing with those of VLW/Ti-6 catalyst. It possibly because more V species covers and blocks the catalyst surface pores. N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms in Fig. S3 show the pore structures of the catalysts are mainly cylindrical mesoporous. Mesoporous structure allows the rapid diffusion of reactants and products, for the mesoporous size (2–50 nm) is larger than the aerodynamic molecular sizes of reactants (0.29 nm for NH3 and 0.35 nm for NO) and products (0.38 nm for N2 and 0.26 nm for H2O) [36,45]. Besides, mesoporous structure has a higher vapor pressure in comparison with microporous, which makes it difficult to deposit NH4HSO4 so that improves the anti-SO2 performance of the catalyst [45]. Surface acidity and redox ability Surface acidity is one of the determining factors for SCR activity of catalyst. NH3 desorption peaks at 100 °C, 200–400 °C and above 400 °C are attributed to the desorption of NH3 from weak, medium strong and strong acid sites on catalyst surface (Fig. 5(a) ) [46,47]. Considering NH3 species anchored on B acid sites are less thermal stability than those adsorbed on L acid sites, the weak/medium strong acid and strong acid are referred to B acid and L acid respectively. In comparison with VLW/Ti-1 and VLW/Ti-12, VLW/Ti-6 has the highest total surface acid amount (Table 1). Meanwhile, the positions of NH3 desorption peaks shift to higher temperature in VLW/Ti-6. The above phenomena reflect that proper desiccation duration can improve the surface acidity of catalyst. Besides, the desorption peak area assigning to B acid decreases in VLW/Ti-6, while that belonging to L acid increases. It possibly because the highly dispersed VO x and WO x species on VLW/Ti-6 create more isolated V=O and W=O structures, which serves as L acid sites for NH3 adsorption [48]. As for VHW/Ti-6, total surface acid sites become fewer but more B acid sites are created comparing with VLW/Ti-6. It can be explained that higher VO x and WO x surface density transfer some of the isolated V=O or W=O structure to polymeric V-O-V, V-O-W or W-O-W structure on VHW/Ti-6. Considering the higher deNO x activity of VHW/Ti-6 at low temperature, B acid sites play an important role in low-temperature NH3-SCR reaction. This result coincides with that of Lai et al. [49]. They found the SCR activity was positively correlated with the number of NH4 + anchoring on B acid sites by in situ IR Spectroscopy. H2-TPR profiles of VW/Ti catalysts are demonstrated in Fig. 5 (b). The peaks at 300–500 °C, 500–600 °C and above 700 °C attribute to the reductions of VO x (or VWO x ) species, V species closely connecting to the catalyst carrier, and WO x species, respectively [50–52]. Comparing with VLW/Ti-1 and VLW/Ti-12, VLW/Ti-6 owns the largest reduction peak area, especially in the range of 300–600 °C. Besides, a new reduction peak at 409 °C appears in the H2-TPR profile of VLW/Ti-6. The above results support that proper desiccation duration can achieve the high distribution of active components on catalyst, which enhances the interaction of active metal atoms with catalyst support and induces the formation of solid solution. The formed solid solution offers more active oxygen species to react with H2 (5.46 mmol/g, as shown in Table 1). It is another main reason explaining the better SCR activity of VLW/Ti-6. The area of the reduction peak at around 378 °C increases in VHW/Ti-6. It manifests that higher V and W loadings facilitate the formation of polymeric VO x and VWO x species with strong oxygen release capacity at low temperature. However, the peak at around 500–600 °C almost disappears and the total H2 consumption of VHW/Ti-6 decreases to 4.07 mmol/g (Table 1). Considering the highest SCR activity of VHW/Ti-6 at low temperature, it is reasonable to believe that the polymeric vanadyl species (e.g., VO x and VWO x ) within the sub-monolayer structure are conductive to NH3-SCR reaction. Similar result was obtained by Zhao et al. [24]. They found the catalyst with polymeric vanadyl species showed higher SCR activity than that with isolated monovanadate species or V2O5 crystallite. Surface elements valence distribution and VO x identification According to the XPS spectra of VW/Ti catalysts in Fig. 6 , surface V atoms mainly exhibit as V5+(517.2 eV) and V4+(516.2 eV). Previous studies indicated that V4+/V5+ ratio is an important prober of oxygen vacancy concentration and has close relationship with surface acidity and redox ability of catalyst [24,33]. As listed in Table 2 , the V4+/V5+ ratio of catalysts decrease as: VHW/Ti-6 (0.86) > VLW/Ti-6 (0.78) > VLW/Ti-1 (0.67) > VLW/Ti-12 (0.66). It is consistent with their NH3-SCR activities. The higher V4+/V5+ ratio in VLW/Ti-6 can be contributed to the high distribution of active components induced by the proper desiccation duration. VHW/Ti-6 owns the highest V4+/V5+ ratio, which is another evidence for the isolated V=O structure has been converted to form the polymeric V-O-V structure [24,50]. W atoms exhibit two main valence states of W6+ (35.7 and 37.7 eV) and W5+(34.9 and 36.7 eV). As listed in Table 2, the variation trend of W6+ content identifies with that of V4+/V5+ ratio. That is because W5+atom easily transfers electron to VO x species via the redox cycle of W5+ + V5+⇌ W6+ + V4+ [50–52]. The O 1s spectra of all catalysts contain three main peaks at the binding energies of 532.7 eV, 531.7 eV and 530 eV, assigning to the oxygen atoms (Oγ) in H2O or OH group [53], chemisorbed oxygen (Oα) and surface lattice oxygen (Oβ), respectively [24]. Among them, Oα is regarded as the most reactive oxygen species in NH3-SCR reaction [36] and can transfer NO to NO2, which initiates the “fast SCR” reaction [24,50,54]. The Oα/(Oα+Oβ+Oγ) value of VLW/Ti-6 (0.34) is higher than those of VLW/Ti-1 and VLW/Ti-12 (0.30 and 0.33). It demonstrates that proper desiccation duration benefits the formation of surface reactive oxygen species. The Oα/(Oα+Oβ+Oγ) value of VHW/Ti-6 further increases to 0.36, coinciding with the larger reduction peak area of VHW/Ti-6 at 300–600 °C and its higher SCR activity at low temperature. The Oγ value of VLW/Ti-1 (0.09) is observed higher than those of VLW/Ti-6 (0.06) and VLW/Ti-12 (0.06). It elucidates that insufficient drying makes more moisture residual on VLW/Ti-1 but excessive drying barely facilitates the evaporation of moisture on VLW/Ti-12. The Oγ value of VHW/Ti-6 rises to 0.11 due to the increase of V content and the formed polymeric vanadyl species. Furthermore, V/Ti and W/Ti ratios on VLW/Ti-6 catalyst are the lowest, indicating more V and W atoms enter bulk catalyst, confirming that partial active components can be distributed onto inner surface of catalyst when proper desiccation duration is conducted. Raman spectrum is frequently used to determine the surface functional groups on catalyst. Besides the vibration of anatase TiO2 at 396, 516 and 638 cm−1 [24,42], peaks assigning to V=O (at around 1070 cm−1), V-O-V (at 991 cm−1) and V-O-Ti (at 958 cm−1) bonds also appear in the Raman spectra of catalysts (Fig. 7 (a)(b)(c)) [24,42,55]. The detection of V=O and V-O-Ti bonds on VLW/Ti-1, VLW/Ti-6 and VLW/Ti-12 surfaces confirm that their VO x species exist mainly in the form of isolated monovanadate species [14]. With the increasing of drying duration, the peak corresponding to V=O shifted to the higher wavenumber, indicating the gradual aggregation of VO x species [55]. Further red shift of the peak assigning to V=O bond as well as the emergence of V-O-V bonds in VHW/Ti-6 catalyst evidently implies the formation of polymeric vanadyl species [54]. Reaction kinetics analysis and key influencing factors determination In general, NH3-SCR reaction on VW/Ti catalyst surface is a first-order reaction of NO [33,56,57]. According to Arrhenius equation, the apparent activation energy (E a) required by the four VW/Ti catalysts for SCR reaction as well as the reaction rate constant (k) was calculated based on the relationship between lnk and 1/T (Fig. 8 ). The calculation detail is described in supplementary material. The E a values increase as VHW/Ti-6 (13.68 kJ/mol) < VLW/Ti-6 (19.31 kJ/mol) < VLW/Ti-12 (27.23 kJ/mol) < VLW/Ti-1 (29.83 kJ/mol). The abundant pore structures as well as better distribution of active components make the NH3-SCR reaction easier to happen. Zhao et al. [24] calculated the E a needed for NH3-SCR reaction on VW/Ti catalysts with different V contents and found the E a value decreased with the increasing of V contents from 1 wt.% to 13 wt.% in the range of 15–26 kJ/mol. The linear fittings of E a values with S BET, VO x /nm2, NH3 desorption, H2 consumption, V4+/V5+ and Oα/(Oα+Oβ+Oγ) are shown in Fig. 9 . Among them, V4+/V5+ ratio (R2 = 0.965) and Oα/(Oα+Oβ+Oγ) value (R 2 = 0.867) exhibit well negative linear correlation with E a. It implies that the surface oxygen vacancy and the chemisorbed oxygen species are the key influencing factors for NH3-SCR reaction. The former can create more reactive oxygen species and facilitate the redox reaction between the adsorbed reactants on catalyst surface. That is coincided with previous studies [24,58,59]. NH3-SCR reaction initiates with the adsorption of reactants on surface acid sites and then follows by the redox reaction with aid of surface reactive oxygen species. The correlation analysis suggests that the redox reaction rather than adsorption turns out to be the rate-determining step for NH3-SCR reaction on the regenerated VW/Ti catalyst. Therefore, optimizing strategies that constructing abundant oxygen vacancy and creating sufficient reactive oxygen species are provided for future catalyst formulating. Conclusion Impregnation method was carried out to replenish active components on the honeycomb V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst. The effects of desiccation duration and impregnation solution concentration on catalytic activity and sulfur/water resistance were studied. The results indicate VLW/Ti-6 shows higher NO x conversion at 150–350 °C than that of VLW/Ti-1 and VLW/Ti-12. Proper drying duration enlarges the specific surface area and pore volume, improves the surface acidic property, enhances the redox capacity and increases V4+/V5+ and Oα/(Oα+Oβ+Oγ) values of catalyst. While insufficient or excessive drying exhibits negative effect. Rising V loading from 1.06 wt.% to 3.61 wt.%, the NO x conversion increases to around 94 % even at 200 °C and is barely affected by the addition of SO2 (50–500 ppm) and H2O (20 vol.%). Reaction kinetics analysis supports the above experiment results and the lowest Ea value (13.68 kJ/mol) is obtained on VHW/Ti-6 catalyst. Linear fitting results exhibit that the V4+/V5+ ratio and Oα/(Oα+Oβ+Oγ) value of catalyst are the key influencing factors for NH3-SCR reaction over VW/Ti catalyst. This study suggests that impregnation method is an effective method to supplement active components on catalyst and further study can be conducted to improve this process for achieving the complete regeneration of the spent catalyst economically and effectively. coredata.dc:description: It is of great economic value and environmental significance to extend the service life of commercial SCR catalysts. Water and acid wash as well as thermal regeneration were often used to remove toxic substances (such as dust, metal sulfates and metal chlorides) residual on catalyst surface so as to reduce the replacement frequency of catalyst, but easily lead to the loss of active components. In this paper, impregnation method was used to supplement the lost active components of the spent honeycombed V2O5-WO3/TiO2 (labeled as VW/Ti) catalyst, and the effects of drying duration and impregnation solution concentration on NH3-SCR performance of catalyst were studied. The results showed that the catalyst dried for 6 h at 110 °C exhibited the best deNO x activity and sulfur/water resistance. Further prolonging or shortening drying duration reduced the catalytic activity instead. It can be attributed that proper drying duration constructs abundant pore channels inside catalyst, optimizes active components dispersion, reduces diffusion resistance of reactants into the inner surface and provides more effective active sites on catalyst surface for adsorption and oxidation of reactants. With rise of V content in impregnation solution from 1.06 wt.% to 3.61 wt.%, deNO x activity as well as SO2/H2O resistance of catalyst improves at 150–300 °C. Besides, key influence factors are also discussed based on reaction kinetics analysis.
coredata.dc:title: Study on impregnation process optimization for regenerating the spent V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalysts
